answer_html: We used, from part (a), that \(\mathbf x_\infty\) is an eigenvector of \(\displaystyle (A-3I)^{-1}\) with eigenvalue \(\eta_3 = 1\).
answer_latex:
We used, from
{part
(a)}, that $\mathbf x_\infty$ is an eigenvector of
$\displaystyle (A-3I)^{-1}$ with eigenvalue $\eta_3 = 1$.
hints_html: Take the limit \(n \to \infty\) on both sides of the definition of \(\mathbf y_n\).
hints_latex:
Take the limit $n \to \infty$ on both sides of the definition of
$\mathbf y_n$.
hints_raw: Take the limit <math>n \to \infty</math> on both sides of the definition of <math>\mathbf y_n</math>.
question: 7 (c)
sols_html:
Taking the limit n \(\rightarrow\) \(\infty\) on both sides yields

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{n \to \infty} \mathbf y_n &= \lim_{n \to \infty} (A-3I)^{-1}\mathbf x_{n-1} \\ &= (A-3I)^{-1} \lim_{n \to \infty}\mathbf x_{n-1} \\ &= (A-3I)^{-1} \mathbf x_\infty \\ &= \eta_3 \mathbf x_\infty \\ &= \mathbf x_\infty = [1/2, 1/2, 1/2, 1/2]^T\end{aligned}\]

We used, from part (a), that \(\mathbf x_\infty\) is an eigenvector of \(\displaystyle (A-3I)^{-1}\) with eigenvalue \(\eta_3 = 1\).
sols_latex:
Taking the limit \emph{n $\rightarrow$ $\infty$} on both sides yields

\begin{align*}
\lim_{n \to \infty} \mathbf y_n &= \lim_{n \to \infty} (A-3I)^{-1}\mathbf x_{n-1} \\
&= (A-3I)^{-1} \lim_{n \to \infty}\mathbf x_{n-1} \\
&= (A-3I)^{-1} \mathbf x_\infty \\
&= \eta_3 \mathbf x_\infty \\
&= \mathbf x_\infty = [1/2, 1/2, 1/2, 1/2]^T
\end{align*}

We used, from
{part
(a)}, that $\mathbf x_\infty$ is an eigenvector of
$\displaystyle (A-3I)^{-1}$ with eigenvalue $\eta_3 = 1$.
sols_raw:
Taking the limit ''n &rarr; &infin;'' on both sides yields

:<math>\begin{align}
\lim_{n \to \infty} \mathbf y_n &= \lim_{n \to \infty} (A-3I)^{-1}\mathbf x_{n-1} \\
&= (A-3I)^{-1} \lim_{n \to \infty}\mathbf x_{n-1} \\
&= (A-3I)^{-1} \mathbf x_\infty \\
&= \eta_3 \mathbf x_\infty \\
&= \mathbf x_\infty = [1/2, 1/2, 1/2, 1/2]^T
\end{align} </math>

We used, from [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_07_(a)|part (a)]], that <math>\mathbf x_\infty</math> is an eigenvector of <math>\displaystyle (A-3I)^{-1}</math> with eigenvalue <math>\eta_3 = 1</math>.
statement_html:
Suppose that A is a symmetric 4x4 matrix with eigenvalues 0, 1, 4, 5. Define a sequence of vectors \(\mathbf{x}_n \in \mathbb{R}^4\) by choosing x0 at random, and then settings

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{y}_n &= (A-3I)^{-1}\mathbf{x}_{n-1} \\ \mathbf{x}_n &= \mathbf{y}_n/\|\mathbf{y}_{n}\|\end{aligned}\]

for n = 1, 2, .... You then observe that xn converges to

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}_\infty = [1/2, 1/2, 1/2, 1/2]^T\end{aligned}\]

as \(n \to \infty\).

(c) What vector does \(\mathbf{y}_n\) converge to?
statement_latex:
Suppose that \emph{A} is a symmetric 4x4 matrix with eigenvalues 0, 1,
4, 5. Define a sequence of vectors $\mathbf{x}_n \in \mathbb{R}^4$ by
choosing \textbf{x}\textsubscript{0} at random, and then settings

\begin{align*}
\mathbf{y}_n &= (A-3I)^{-1}\mathbf{x}_{n-1} \\
\mathbf{x}_n &= \mathbf{y}_n/\|\mathbf{y}_{n}\|
\end{align*}

for \emph{n = 1, 2, ...}. You then observe that
\textbf{x}\textsubscript{n} converges to

\begin{align*}
\mathbf{x}_\infty = [1/2, 1/2, 1/2, 1/2]^T
\end{align*}

as $n \to \infty$.

\textbf{(c)} What vector does $\mathbf{y}_n$ converge to?
statement_raw:
Suppose that ''A'' is a symmetric 4x4 matrix with eigenvalues 0, 1, 4, 5. Define a sequence of vectors <math>\mathbf{x}_n \in \mathbb{R}^4</math> by choosing '''x'''<sub>0</sub> at random, and then settings

:<math> \begin{align}
\mathbf{y}_n &= (A-3I)^{-1}\mathbf{x}_{n-1} \\
\mathbf{x}_n &= \mathbf{y}_n/\|\mathbf{y}_{n}\|
\end{align} </math>

for ''n = 1, 2, ...''. You then observe that '''x'''<sub>n</sub> converges to

:<math>
\mathbf{x}_\infty = [1/2, 1/2, 1/2, 1/2]^T
</math>

as <math> n \to \infty</math>.

'''(c)''' What vector does <math>\mathbf{y}_n</math> converge to?
